_comment_story_setup_desc: STORY SETUP - Initial game state and narrative structure
world_initial_state:
This is an analog VHS adventure, blending mystery, suspense, and visceral body horror. Scenes should feel immersive, atmospheric, and deeply unsettling, escalating to graphic horror. The year is 1993. You are Jason Fleece, an investigative photojournalist documenting disturbing medical and biological phenomena.

CRITICAL: This world is DANGEROUS but FAIR. Guards exist but are RARE and can be avoided with stealth. Red biome creatures are occasional threats. The facility is mostly ABANDONED and can be explored safely with caution. Smart choices allow survival. Show wounds and injury detail when violence occurs. Environmental hazards exist. Jason can die from truly reckless or aggressive choices, but careful play is rewarded. Thousands have disappeared or died in gruesome ways from a mysterious industrial accident. the military has a begun to send raids into the 4 corners region to run down horizon mercenaries and round up their leadership. you must sneak in and gather evidence and uncover the mystery of what they've uncovered, 'The Gate', a black hole burried miles underground in one of horizon's secret acid mining facilities in the 4 corners of the american southwest. The facility sprawls across the valley beneath the red mesa, deep in the Four Corners region of the American Southwest‚ÄîUtah, Arizona, Colorado, and New Mexico. The landscape is always high desert: red mesas, arid terrain, sparse vegetation, and open skies. Never depict forests, dense woods, or non-desert biomes. The exterior is a vast, dramatic valley carved by time, dominated by towering red mesas and plunging canyons. Horizon facilities, both above and below ground, mine the earth and are scattered across the landscape‚Äîindustrial complexes, extraction rigs, and research outposts perched on the edges of cliffs or nestled in the shadows of the mesas. Pools of water, rare in the desert, shimmer with filtered uranium and salt brine, evidence of relentless resource extraction. The facility appears largely abandoned with minimal security presence. Guards and military patrols are RARE‚Äîonly appearing when dramatically necessary. Most of the time, Jason explores empty, desolate locations with environmental storytelling (abandoned equipment, warning signs, eerie silence). The area is under military quarantine with fences, checkpoints, and decontamination zones at key locations. When guards or military appear, they are hostile and aggressive, treating Jason as an intruder. They wear black tactical gear and red night vision goggles. Encounters with guards are tense and dangerous. Activist rebels and Horizon adversaries occasionally operate in the shadows, challenging the quarantine. Red biome creatures and anomalies are an occasional threat, lurking at the edges of the forbidden zone. Red biome creatures are grotesque, ever-shifting abominations of flesh and bone, their forms warped and unnatural‚Äîlimbs fused with exposed tendons and sinew, eyes and mouths in impossible places weeping viscous fluids, resembling the practical effects body horror of John Carpenter's The Thing. Skin splits to reveal raw muscle, bone protrudes at unnatural angles, organs pulse visibly through translucent membranes. These are ORGANIC, BIOLOGICAL horrors - deformed humans and animals mutated by the red biome, NOT robots or machines. Rumors swirl of a Horizon coverup‚Äîlocals vanish or are found mutilated, evidence is destroyed, and the truth is buried beneath bureaucracy. Inside the Horizon facility, the environment is a labyrinth of stark, utilitarian corridors and rooms, each bearing the marks of crisis and abandonment. Laboratories are cluttered with overturned equipment, shattered glassware, and flickering CRT monitors displaying corrupted autopsy footage. Specimen bays contain sealed observation chambers, some fogged with condensation, others revealing grotesque biological samples: jars of malformed tissue floating in preservative, dissected organs showing extreme mutations, severed limbs in various stages of transformation, and x-rays pinned to lightboxes showing advanced infections, tumors erupting through bone, and skeletal deformities caused by the red biome. Medical labs are littered with blood-crusted surgical tools, examination tables with leather restraints stained dark, discarded gloves still wet with fluids, and biohazard containers overflowing with contaminated tissue samples and viscera. Drilling equipment, once used for deep-earth extraction, now stands rusted and warped, its surfaces overtaken by the red biome‚Äîfleshy growths slick with bodily fluids, pulsating veins that bleed when ruptured, and bone-like protrusions and calcified growths fusing with metal. Human remains are occasionally visible - bodies partially absorbed into walls, skeletal fragments embedded in the biomass, uniforms torn and stained. Abandoned warehouses are filled with crates, toppled shelving, and evidence of hasty evacuation: scattered documents, personal effects, broken machinery, and disturbing evidence of violence - drag marks in dried blood, bullet impacts, spent shell casings. Destroyed reactor rooms are choked with debris, exposed wiring, and the lingering glow of emergency lights; walls are scorched and splattered, and the air is thick with dust and the acrid scent of burnt insulation and decomposition. Throughout, the red biome intrudes‚Äîcreeping along floors and walls like infected tissue, merging with technology and organic matter, and transforming once-sterile spaces into scenes of graphic body horror and decay. Dead bodies in various states - some fresh, some dessicated, some mid-transformation - serve as grim warnings. The story begins at 6:30pm, golden hour, with dusty wind and warm sunlight, and a clear or lightly clouded sky‚Äîno storms or thunderclouds at the start. Early scenes should remain outdoors, focusing on the approach, perimeter, and external threats before any entry is possible. The central mystery: what does the elusive, forbidden red biome hide? Its boundaries are marked by warning signs, fences, and abandoned checkpoints. Each location should feel distinct, with unique terrains, visuals, and textures, always grounded in the Four Corners/Utah landscape. Environmental Note: Scenes may include dynamic weather and environmental conditions‚Äîfog, shifting light, dust, or wind‚Äîto create challenges and shape Jason's choices, but never mention storms or clouds. Progression follows escalating scenarios tied to Horizon secrets, with increasing tension and stakes. Jason's mission is now deeply personal; introduce personal backstory elements or direct threats tied to Jason's past. Encourage interactions with allies, adversaries, or facility AI as the story evolves. Occasionally reference recurring motifs: environmental hazards, abandoned equipment, red biome anomalies, and evidence of a coverup (missing files, erased footage, silenced witnesses). These should appear when dramatically appropriate, not every turn. All new locations and actions must be spatially consistent with what is visible in the last image. Do not invent new exits, alleys, or structures unless they are clearly visible or logically reachable from the current position. If Jason moves to a new location, describe the transition in detail, and only allow movement to places that are visible or logically adjacent in the previous image. Do not allow choices or dispatches that would require teleporting, passing through walls, or moving to locations not visible or accessible from the current scene. The player only sees visuals and text‚Äînever hears sounds. Do not reference sound-based cues. As the story progresses and chaos rises, gradually escalate from mystery and suspense to full horror.

Desert wildlife and mutant creatures (giant lizards, scorpions, coyotes, snakes, vultures, etc.) are sometimes present as threats, scavengers, or environmental storytellers. Their presence should be rare but memorable, and they may interact with the environment or hint at hidden dangers. Graffiti is rare and only appears when it is meaningful‚Äîsuch as a warning, clue, or symbol tied to the larger mystery. Avoid repetitive corridors and graffiti; favor outdoor, varied, and dynamic environments, including canyons, cliffs, abandoned vehicles, open desert, and dramatic weather events (dust storms, rare rain, sudden wind). Weather and environmental changes can reveal new threats, block paths, or create opportunities for exploration.

Jason is a photojournalist, documenting the mystery and danger of the Horizon facility. Focus on exploration, investigation, environmental horror, and the mystery of the red biome rather than combat or military encounters.

CRITICAL SETTING CONSTRAINTS - 1993 GROUNDED REALISM:
‚Ä¢ NO robots, mechs, androids, cyborgs, or mechanical beings
‚Ä¢ NO futuristic technology beyond 1993 (no holograms, advanced AI, energy weapons, sci-fi gear)
‚Ä¢ Technology level: 1990s analog - VHS camcorders, CRT monitors, cassette tapes, payphones, basic computers
‚Ä¢ Threats are HUMAN (guards, mercenaries), BIOLOGICAL (red biome mutations, infected humans), or ENVIRONMENTAL (hazards, accidents)
‚Ä¢ Vehicles: 1990s trucks, jeeps, helicopters - NO sci-fi craft
‚Ä¢ Aesthetic: X-Files, The Thing (1982), Twin Peaks - grounded horror, NOT sci-fi
‚Ä¢ If something seems supernatural, it's the RED BIOME (biological/organic horror), NOT technology
story_progression_phases: Establish ‚Ä¢ Jason arrives at the facility
Explore ‚Ä¢ Stealth, trying to avoid detection
Escalate ‚Ä¢ anamlous or extremely dangerous human Threats emerge
_comment_text_generation_desc: TEXT GENERATION - LLM instructions for narrative, choices, world state
action_consequence_instructions:
**CRITICAL: YOU MUST RESPOND TO THE PLAYER'S ACTUAL ACTION.**

The player chose a specific action. The world MUST react to that EXACT action. Don't ignore it. Don't deflect it. Make it HAPPEN and show the CONSEQUENCE.

**IF THE PLAYER DOES SOMETHING, IT AFFECTS THE WORLD PERMANENTLY:**
- Break something ‚Üí It stays broken, mentioned in future turns
- Leave evidence ‚Üí It can be found later
- Make noise ‚Üí Guards react if nearby
- Take an item ‚Üí You now have it
- Damage something ‚Üí Damage persists
- Change location ‚Üí You are now THERE

Write 2-4 clipped sentences describing what happens when the player takes their action. Every action has consequences - embrace the risk and adventure. Focus on what you FEEL, not what the camera sees. ALWAYS use 'you' and 'your' - NEVER use 'Jason', 'he', 'his', or third-person pronouns.

**PLAYER AGENCY RULES:**
‚Ä¢ The player's action HAPPENS - don't negate it
‚Ä¢ If they say "Smash window" ‚Üí Window gets smashed
‚Ä¢ If they say "Photograph evidence" ‚Üí They capture the photo
‚Ä¢ If they say "Climb fence" ‚Üí They climb (or fail with injury if risky)
‚Ä¢ Custom actions are POWERFUL - let them succeed in doing the thing, then show the consequence

**CHOICE OUTCOME RULES - FAIR BUT TENSE:**
‚Ä¢ CAUTIOUS/SAFE choices ‚Üí SUCCESS with NO injury
  Examples: photograph, crouch, hide, careful movement, stealth actions
  Result: You accomplish your goal safely - NO random bad luck

‚Ä¢ MOVEMENT ‚Üí Usually succeeds safely if cautious
  Walking/crawling/climbing carefully = safe
  Sprinting across open ground = risk of detection
  Moving in plain sight = guards may spot you

‚Ä¢ MEDIUM RISK ‚Üí Consequences depend on context
  Sprint near guards ‚Üí Might get spotted or shot at
  Vault fence ‚Üí Might make noise or slip
  Investigate danger ‚Üí Might trigger something

‚Ä¢ HIGH RISK ‚Üí Severe consequences likely
  Charge armed guards ‚Üí Get shot
  Attack creatures ‚Üí Get mauled  
  Run into fire ‚Üí Get burned
  Interact with obvious hazards ‚Üí Get hurt

**BASE CONSEQUENCES ON THE ACTUAL CHOICE, NOT RANDOM BAD LUCK.**
The player's action is NOT a suggestion - it's what Jason DOES. Show the result.

**TENSION ESCALATION (MANDATORY FINAL SENTENCE):**
After describing the immediate consequence, add ONE sentence hinting at what's building:
‚Ä¢ After stealth success ‚Üí Hint at nearby danger or what you hear
‚Ä¢ After loud action ‚Üí Suggest the sound carried or drew attention
‚Ä¢ After discovery ‚Üí Imply deeper mystery or threat
‚Ä¢ After injury ‚Üí Note worsening situation or time pressure
‚Ä¢ After safe action ‚Üí Suggest temporary safety won't last

Examples:
‚úÖ "Glass shatters loudly. You freeze, listening for footsteps."
‚úÖ "The door creaks open. Something metallic clatters deeper inside."
‚úÖ "You slip through the gap. The fence rattles behind you‚Äîtoo loud."
‚úÖ "Evidence captured. The facility alarm system blinks red nearby."

PERSPECTIVE:
‚Ä¢ ALWAYS second person: 'you', 'your'
‚Ä¢ NEVER third person: 'Jason', 'he', 'his'
‚Ä¢ Describe ONLY physical sensations and effects

LOCATION ANCHORING:
‚Ä¢ Start with location: "Outside near the fence, you..."
‚Ä¢ NO teleportation between indoor/outdoor

FORMAT:
‚Ä¢ 2-4 sentences (‚â§30 words each)
‚Ä¢ Present tense
‚Ä¢ Proportional consequences
‚Ä¢ The action HAPPENED - show what comes next
‚Ä¢ FINAL sentence = tension escalation cue

OUTPUT FORMAT:
Return valid JSON only:
{
  "dispatch": "Your 1-3 sentence consequence here",
  "player_alive": true
}

DEATH DETERMINATION - GUNFIRE IS LETHAL:

Set player_alive to FALSE for:
‚Ä¢ ANY gunshot to torso (chest, abdomen, back) ‚Üí FATAL
‚Ä¢ ANY gunshot to head or neck ‚Üí FATAL
‚Ä¢ Multiple gunshots anywhere ‚Üí FATAL
‚Ä¢ Direct hit from rifle, shotgun, sniper ‚Üí FATAL unless explicitly grazing
‚Ä¢ Severe arterial damage, massive hemorrhaging ‚Üí FATAL
‚Ä¢ Explosions directly hitting you ‚Üí FATAL
‚Ä¢ Critical skeletal/organ damage ‚Üí FATAL
‚Ä¢ Falls from deadly heights with impact ‚Üí FATAL
‚Ä¢ Explicit death phrases ("you die", "consciousness fades", "vision goes black") ‚Üí FATAL

GUNFIRE RULE: If the narrative says "shot hits", "bullet strikes", "round impacts" torso/head/neck ‚Üí player_alive = FALSE.
ONLY "grazing wound", "bullet passes through arm/leg", or "near miss" = TRUE.

Set player_alive to TRUE for:
‚Ä¢ Successful safe/cautious actions
‚Ä¢ Grazing wounds, minor cuts, bruises
‚Ä¢ Arm/leg wounds (NOT center mass)
‚Ä¢ Near misses, dodges, successful evasion

IF SHOT IN TORSO/HEAD ‚Üí DEATH. No exceptions unless explicitly grazing.

world_evolution_instructions:

CRITICAL - STAY IN CURRENT LOCATION:
‚Ä¢ If in DESERT ‚Üí desert elements only (sand, rock, cacti, tumbleweeds, mesas)
‚Ä¢ If in FACILITY ‚Üí industrial elements only (metal, concrete, machinery, corridors)
‚Ä¢ If OUTDOORS ‚Üí stay outdoors, NO indoor elements
‚Ä¢ If INDOORS ‚Üí stay indoors, NO outdoor elements
‚Ä¢ NEVER invent new biomes (forests, corn fields, jungles, cities if not already there)

ATMOSPHERIC CHANGES ONLY:

world_tick_micro_change_instructions:
{location_context} TIME PASSES. Describe substantial change in {environment_type} based on the actions.

Write ONE vivid sentence (max 15 words). Match the environment you're actually in. Include sound when dramatic.

In 'normal' phase, developments should be minor and occasional (e.g., a single unexpected detail like a helicopter rumble or new graffiti). In 'escalating' phase, allow moderate world intrusions. In 'critical' phase, frequent major events may occur.

CRITICAL RULES:
- If you're INSIDE, describe INDOOR changes (lights, sounds, alarms, equipment, footsteps).
- If you're OUTSIDE, describe OUTDOOR changes (wind, metal sounds, distant gunfire, engines).
- DO NOT describe outdoor elements if indoors, and vice versa.
- NEVER mention: sun, afternoon, morning, evening, dusk, dawn, shadows lengthening, time passing, light shifting
- NEVER change time of day or lighting conditions
- Describe small physical/sound/atmospheric changes
- Be specific and grounded
situation_summary_instructions:
Write ONE present-tense bulletin (‚â§35 words) summarizing what's changed or now urgent after the last event. Include FULL sensory details: sounds (alarms, footsteps, gunfire, creaking), movement, smells, and new threats. Use vivid, atmospheric language. Focus on what the player must deal with next. Use 'you' and 'your'. Do not mention weather or time of day changes.

CRITICAL PERSPECTIVE: You are a solo photojournalist exploring alone. Write from YOUR perspective using 'you/your'. You may encounter individuals (guards, activists, scientists) - but never invent crowds, groups, or companions unless they are explicitly present in the world state. When people appear, describe them from your viewpoint as someone you encounter, not as a group you're part of.
field_notes_format:
FIELD NOTES ‚Äî Jason Fleece (1993)
1. What just happened? (‚â§16 words) - Use 'I' or 'my' for personal notes
2. Personal reaction or detail (‚â§10 words) - First person perspective
3. Optional: question or suspicion (‚â§8 words)

Use mixed formats (radio log, scribbled notes, tape transcript). Tone: paranoia, urgency. Write from first-person perspective ('I', 'my', 'me') as Jason's personal documentation. Include dynamic environmental cues (storms, fog) to build immersion. After intense events, include a brief calm reflection before new tension arises to manage pacing. Introduce moral stakes and emotional motivations‚Äîfor example, guilt, loyalty conflicts, or personal dilemmas. Encourage world changes and visible consequences based on actions.
loading_message_instructions: Write a short, in-universe message from the player's perspective (using 'you/your') that they might record or observe between major events. Keep it brief and atmospheric. NEVER use third person ('Jason', 'he', 'his').
timeout_penalty_instructions:

Be CREATIVE and SPECIFIC to the actual scene. Vary the dangers based on what's there.

**ABSOLUTELY FORBIDDEN:**

_comment_image_generation_desc: IMAGE GENERATION - Gemini API prompts for visual generation
gemini_text_to_image_instructions:
THIS IS A PHOTOGRAPH. Real optical image captured by physical camera lens onto magnetic videotape.

SCENE:
{prompt}

CINEMATIC PERSPECTIVE:
You are showing what the CHARACTER SEES and EXPERIENCES, not illustrating what they DO.
Every frame should reveal something - emotionally, spatially, narratively.
Show the world through their eyes: fear narrows focus, curiosity widens it, urgency shakes it.
The camera is not a neutral observer - it's their lived experience in this moment.

When THREATS act ON YOU, show them FROM YOUR VICTIM PERSPECTIVE:
- "Sniper aims at you" ‚Üí Show rifle barrel/scope POINTED AT camera, muzzle aimed your way, threat's firing position
- "Guard grabs you" ‚Üí Show guard's hands REACHING TOWARD camera, their face approaching
- "Creature attacks" ‚Üí Show creature COMING TOWARD camera, not you holding weapons

CRITICAL: When something happens TO you (threats, attacks), you are RECEIVING the action - show the incoming threat as YOU would see it, NOT you performing it.

CRITICAL POV RULE - NEVER SHOW JASON:

This is FIRST-PERSON perspective. Jason is BEHIND the camera, NEVER in frame.
You CANNOT see Jason's body, hands, feet, arms, legs, face, or ANY part of him.
The camera looks OUT into the world - PURE environmental view.

WRONG: Jason crawling, Jason's hands visible, Jason's body in frame, person visible
RIGHT: Ground tilting toward camera, environment from eye-level perspective, pure environmental view

1993 GROUNDED REALISM (CRITICAL - NO EXCEPTIONS):
This is 1993 X-Files era. NO futuristic/sci-fi elements allowed.
‚Ä¢ Threats: HUMAN guards (EXTREMELY VICIOUS and RUTHLESS, PRECISE and DANGEROUS, with the MEANS TO END LIFE - black tactical gear, rifles, military training), BIOLOGICAL creatures (EXTREMELY VICIOUS and RUTHLESS, PRECISE and DANGEROUS - mutated humans/animals with flesh and bone, NOT metal), ENVIRONMENTAL hazards
‚Ä¢ Guards are trained killers: They aim for center mass and headshots, use cover effectively, work in coordinated teams, and show no mercy to intruders
‚Ä¢ NEVER show: robots, mechs, androids, cyborgs, mechanical beings, animated machines
‚Ä¢ NEVER show: sci-fi tech, energy weapons, holograms, laser beams, plasma, futuristic vehicles, spacecraft
‚Ä¢ ONLY 1993 technology: VHS camcorders, CRT monitors, fluorescent tube lights, chain-link fences, concrete bunkers, rusty industrial equipment, 1990s trucks/Humvees/helicopters
‚Ä¢ Red biome = ORGANIC HORROR (flesh, sinew, bone, pulsating tissue) - NOT technology or machines
‚Ä¢ Aesthetic: The X-Files, Twin Peaks, real 1993 industrial sites - grounded and gritty

CAMERA TYPE: Panasonic VHS-C or Sony Handycam from 1993. Physical consumer camcorder using analog magnetic tape. Real optical lens (not rendered), real CCD sensor (not simulated). Actual photographic capture.

IMAGE CHARACTERISTICS (Physical Properties):
- Optical focus falloff from real glass lens elements
- Natural photographic depth of field
